children.name: from the beginning
children.definition: /startB1
examples: từ lúc đầu
▪ Tell me everything that happened, from the beginning.
hãy nói cho tôi chuyện gì đã xảy ra từ lúc bắt đầu
▪ Their marriage has been in trouble from the start.
Cuộc hôn nhân của họ đã có vấn đề ngay cả khi từ lúc bắt đầu
right from the beginning/startfrom the very earliest time:Ngaytừ lúc bắt đầu
▪ Right from the start I could tell she didn’t like me.
Ngay từ lúc bắt đầu tôi đã biết được rằng cô ấy không thích tôi
▪ Mark felt very comfortable in his new job, right from the beginning.
Ngay từ lúc bắt đầu Mark đã cảm thấy rất thoải mái trong côngviệc mới
from start to finishfrom the beginning to the end:từ đầu đến cuối
▪ This project has been a complete nightmare from start to finish.
Dự án này thật sự là một cơn ác mộng ngay từ lúc bắt đầu cho đến khi kết thúc

children.name: from the word go
children.definition: /frəm ðə ˌwɜːʳd ˈgəʊ/ informalfrom the beginning - used especially when something has happened or existedcontinuouslysince the beginning:
examples: từ lúc ban đầu ( liên tục )
▪ Eva’s been very supportive from the word go.
▪ The Elfin Theatre Company was doomed to failure from the word go.

children.name: from day one U
children.definition: since/from day one/sɪns, frəm ˌdeɪ ˈwʌn/  if something has been the situation or has been someone’s purpose since or from day one, it has clearly been the situation or their purpose ever since the beginning : ngay từ đầu
examples: ▪ From day one I knew we’d have a strong team this year.
▪ We’ve opposed this amendment since day one and we’d be stupid to change our minds now.

children.name: from the outset
children.definition: from the time when a continuing activity or process began : từ lúc bắt đầu ( liên tục )
examples: ▪ The new group had, from the outset, campaigned for an improvement in childcare provision.
▪ I was determined from the outset to make the most of going to university.

children.name: at the beginning
children.definition: /startB1
examples: lúc đầu
▪ At the start it looked as though Italy would win, but Argentina improved as the game went on.
Lúc đầu thì có lẽ như Italy sẽ thắng nhưng Argentina đã cải thiện khi trận đấu tiếp diễn
▪ She was nervous at the beginning but she settled down as she got further into her speech.
Cô ấy đã rất lo lắng ngay từ đầu nhưng cô ấy đã ổn định khi tiếp tục bài phát biểu
at the beginning/start of
▪ We pay our rent at the beginning of the month.
Chúng tôi trả tiền thuê nhà vào đầu mỗi tháng
▪ For homework tonight, start at the beginning of chapter three and read up to page 98.
Đối với bài tập về nhà tối nay, bắt đầu từ chương 3 và đọc đến trang 98
▪ At the start of the century, barely 3% of the population was literate.
Vào đầu thế kỷ đó, chỉ có 3% dân số biết chữ

children.name: at first
children.definition: / initially B2 use this to say what happened at the beginning, especially when something different happened later.Initially is more formal than at first:
examples: lúc đầu ( đặc biệt là lúc sau có cái gì khác xảy ra )
▪ Barney was quiet at first, but gradually he became more confident.
▪ At first I didn’t think Nancy and I would get along.
▪ They offered her the job, initially on a temporary basis but later as a full member of the staff.
initial[adjective only before noun] bắt đầu, ban đầu
▪ My initial impression of Sadie was that she was shy and a little unhappy.
Ấn tượng ban đầu của tôi về Sadie là cô ấy khá ngượng ngùng và có một chút không vui

children.name: originally
children.definition: lúc đầu, ban đầu
examples: at the beginning (use this to talk about the situation at the time in the past when something first started)
Originally, they told me I was only going to work 35 hours a week.
Two hundred people showed up for the wedding, about 50 more than we originally planned.
originallysung[only passive]
All major types of Chinese poetry were originally sung to the accompaniment of music.

children.name: to start/begin with
children.definition: to start with/to begin with/tə ˈstɑːʳt wɪð, tə bɪˈgɪn wɪð/  especiallyspokenuse this to talk about what happens at the beginning, especially when something different may happen later:
examples: bắt đầu với
▪ Our employees receive health benefits and $28,000 a year to start with.
Nhân viên của chúng tôi nhận được trợ cấp về sức khỏe bắt đầu là 28000 đô một năm
▪ Even children who are healthy to begin with wouldn’t survive long in these terrible conditions.
Ngay cả những đứa trẻ khỏe mạnh lúc ban đầu cũng không sống sót qua được những điều kiện khủng khiếp này

children.name: at the outset
children.definition: /ət ði ˈaʊtset/ formalif something isknown,believed,decidedetcat the outset, it is known etc from the very earliest point in a period of time or activity:
examples: ngay từ lúc đầu ( đã biết, tin , quyết định ... )
▪ Sylvia knew at the outset what her ultimate goals were.
Sylvia đã biết ngay từ đầu những mục tiêu cuối cùng của cô là gì
▪ It had been decided at the outset that Theresa would be our spokesperson.
Ngay đầu đã quyết định rằng Theresa sẽ là người phát ngôn của chúng tôi

children.name: first
children.definition: /fɜːʳst/  before everyone or everything else: trước tiên, đầu tiên
examples: ▪ Laurie’s name was first on the list.
▪ I still remember my first day of school.
▪ She had her first baby in 1998.
▪ I’ve only read the first chapter, but it seems like a really good book.
▪ The first thing I ever had published was an article for the Boy Scout magazine.
first[adv] before you do any other things, or before anything else happens: trước tiên, đầu tiên
▪ I always read the sports page of the newspaper first.
▪ Shall we go out now, or do you want to eat first?
▪ I’ll help you with your homework, but first let me finish the dishes.

children.name: first of all
children.definition: at the beginning, before other events or actions - use this especially to say what you should do or what you did do first: trước tiên
examples: ▪ First of all, fry the onions.
▪ First of all, let me welcome everyone to the meeting.
▪ First of all I went to tell my wife and then my daughter and son-in-law what had happened.

children.name: original
children.definition: /əˈrɪdʒɪnəl, -dʒənəl/  use this about something that existed at the beginning, especially before a lot of things were changed:
examples: ▪ The house still has its original stone floors.
▪ Our original plan was to go camping, but it was pouring with rain.

children.name: initial
children.definition: /ɪˈnɪʃəl/  use this to talk about what happened at the beginning of a process or activity or what someone felt at the beginning, especially when this changes later: ban đầu lúc đầu
examples: initial response/reaction/feeling etc
▪ My initial reaction was one of complete disbelief.
▪ After the initial shock, people adjusted to the new circumstances.
initial difficulties/problems/setbacks etc
▪ Initial difficulties with the computer system were soon fixed.
initial stage/trial/step etc
▪ I was only involved in the initial stages of the planning.
▪ Classes in gun handling are recommended as the initial step for those who want to own a handgun.
initially[adverb] ban đầu
▪ Far fewer people have applied for the visas than the government initially expected.

children.name: earliest
children.definition: /ˈɜːʳliɪst, ˈɜːʳliəst/  happening or existing before all others: sớm nhất
examples: ▪ ‘The Comedy of Errors’ is one of Shakespeare’s earliest plays.
▪ The earliest form of transport was probably some kind of sledge.
▪ Ginger was one of the earliest oriental spices known to Europeans.

children.name: the first time
children.definition: use this to say that something happens that has never happened before: lần đầu tiên
examples: the first time (that)
▪ The first time I went on a plane I was really nervous.
▪ It was the first time that she had seen her mother cry.
for the first time
▪ For the first time, representatives from the two countries will talk at a conference table.

children.name: unprecedented
children.definition: /ʌnˈpresɪdentəd, ʌnˈpresədentəd/  something that is unprecedented has never happened before and is usually unexpected: chưa từng thấy
examples: ▪ An unprecedented number of cars entered the race.
▪ The police took the unprecedented step of publishing the victim’s photograph.
▪ The depression that started in mid-1929 was a catastrophe of unprecedented dimensions for the United States.

children.name: done or happening at the beginning
initial
children.definition: /ɪˈnɪʃəl/ initialfeelings/costs/reaction etcfeelings, costs etc that exist or are experienced at the beginning of an event or process: ban đầu
examples: ▪ Simon’s initial feeling when he heard about the wedding was surprise.
▪ After initial delays, construction on the new library is due to start in two weeks.
▪ The initial cost of the computer system is more than made up for in terms of eventual profit.

children.name: early
children.definition: /ˈɜːʳli/  close to the beginning of an event, story, period of time etc: đầu
examples: ▪ I’ll be seeing him early next week.
early in the game/story/century etc:
▪ Rangers scored early in the game but fell behind within ten minutes.
early[adjective only before noun] A1
▪ We’re planning to go to Barcelona in early September.
▪ He was described as a man in his early thirties between 30 and 33 years old.
▪ the story of her early life in India :

children.name: preliminary
children.definition: happening at the beginning of a process or event, especially in order to prepare for the rest of it: mở đầu, ban đầu, sơ bộ
examples: ▪ The architect’s plans are still in the preliminary stages
▪ Preliminary market research has shown that most Americans prefer environmentally-friendly products.

children.name: introductory
children.definition: /ˌɪntrəˈdʌktəri/ introductory remark/paragraph/chapter etcsth sb says or writes at the beginning of a book, speech etc to explain what it is about: giới thiệu, mở đầu, mở bài
examples: ▪ Williams cleared his throat, made a few introductory remarks welcoming everyone, then began his speech.
▪ The text has been revised and a new introductory essay has been added for the second edition.

children.name: opening
children.definition: /ˈəʊpənɪŋ/  said or written at the beginning of a speech, book, play etc: giới thiệu, mở đầu
examples: ▪ In the opening chapter, Ramona sits at the breakfast table thinking about the first day of school.
▪ The audience strongly objected to the opening remarks of the president’s speech.
▪ Hilary makes a brief appearance in the opening scene, but doesn’t have a major part.

children.name: when sth is the first thing you want to say
first
children.definition: / firstlyB2 spoken say this to introduce the first fact, reason, or question, when you are going to mention several more things: trước hết là
examples: ▪ I wanted to change schools, firstly because I didn’t like the teacher and secondly because it was too far away.
▪ First, may I say that I am extremely grateful for the trust my colleagues have put in me.
▪ African leaders are worried, firstly about the official flow of aid, and also about levels of private investment.

children.name: first of all
children.definition: spoken say this when the reason you are giving first is the most important one: trước hết là
examples: ▪ Freddy, first of all, I didn’t flirt with him. He flirted with me.
▪ I called the book ‘Drum Planet’ because first of all, there are drums in every culture.

children.name: to start with
children.definition: to start/begin with spoken say this when your reason or fact is the most easy to see or understand: để bắt đầu, bắt đầu với
examples: ▪ To start with, one of the biggest problems in the classroom is that the kids don’t get enough discipline at home.
▪ Working at home is a good option, because, to begin with, what’s the point of driving two hours a day just to sit in front of a computer?

children.name: in the first place
children.definition: alsofor a startBritish /ɪn ðə ˈfɜːʳst pleɪs, fər ə ˈstɑːʳt/  spoken say this when you are arguing or discussing something with someone and you are going to give the main reason that proves that what you are saying is true: để bắt đầu
examples: ▪ In the first place, they have a more experienced team, so they’re more likely to win.
▪ We haven’t made a decision, because, in the first place, we do not know enough at this point.
▪ For a start, someone’s sex should not matter in a job interview.

children.name: before I start U
children.definition: before I startspoken say this when you are going to say something before you start the main part of a speech or talk to a group of people: trước khi bắt đầu
examples: ▪ Before I start, I’d like to thank everyone for coming.
▪ All right, before I start, could everyone please stand up and introduce themselves.

children.name: a first
children.definition: /ə ˈfɜːʳst/  something that has never been done or achieved by anyone before and is therefore surprising or exciting: lần đầu tiên
examples: ▪ If an animated film was nominated as best picture, it would be a first.
a first in
▪ Roger Bannister’s four-minute mile was a notable first in the history of athletics.
▪ During the 1960's, the Soviet Union achieved a series of firsts in space exploration.
a first for
▪ Delivering a baby on the job was a first for the two police officers.

children.name: prototype
children.definition: /ˈprəʊtətaɪp/  the first model of something, especially of a machine or a new invention, that is often improved in later models: nguyên mẫu
examples: ▪ No damage to the prototype aircraft was reported after its first test flight.
prototype of nguyên mẫu của
▪ Pilots have begun testing a prototype of the new aircraft.
▪ The prototype of this particular computer was developed by an American in 1975.
prototype for nguyên mẫu cho
▪ Within a year, the company expects to have a prototype for military use.

children.name: original
children.definition: /əˈrɪdʒɪnəl, -dʒənəl/  something such as a picture or a piece of writing that is not a copy but is the one produced for the first time by the artist or writer themselves: bản chính
examples: ▪ I wasn’t sure whether the portrait was an excellent copy or the original.
▪ This is a photograph of the manuscript. The original is in the city museum.
original[adjective] bản chính
▪ Only a millionaire could afford to buy an original Picasso a picture by Picasso that is not a copy.

children.name: first-generation
children.definition: /ˌfɜːʳst dʒenəˈreɪʃən/  first-generation computers, machines etc were the first ones of their type to be produced, and are the ones that later computers, machines etc of the same type are based on: thế hệ đầu tiên
examples: ▪ The first-generation digital televisions cost over $2000.
▪ There were a variety of problems common to first-generation computer software programs.
first generation[singular noun] first-generation of thế hệ đầu tiên của
▪ The first generation of cellular phones used analog transmitters and receivers.

children.name: maiden
children.definition: /ˈmeɪdn/  maiden voyage/flight/speech the first one that a particular ship, aircraft, or person makes: đầu tiên
examples: ▪ The Titanic sank on its maiden voyage.
▪ Two jets crashed on their maiden flights last year.
▪ The new prime minister admitted that her maiden speech had been too long.

children.name: inaugural
children.definition: /ɪˈnɔːgjɑrəl/  inaugural lecture/address/speech etc one that an important person does or makes when they first start a new job:
examples: nhậm chức
▪ The inaugural address drew a large audience.
▪ Professor Eston gave the inaugural lecture in 1860.
